title: The Animal-Based Debate: Is Paul Saladino Right About Honey and Fruit?
author: Carnivore Weekly
description: Carnivore vs animal-based breakdown. Paul Saladino's honey and fruit argument, strict carnivore counterpoints, what the community actually experiences, and how to decide which protocol works for you.
content_html:
Okay, so Paul Saladino is all over your feed talking about honey, fruit, and raw milk. He used to be hardcore carnivore. Now he's calling it "animal-based" and adding carbs back in.

And you're wondering: Did he betray the movement? Or did he figure something out that strict carnivores are missing?

TL;DR

  • Paul Saladino's argument‚Äîactive people may do better with honey and fruit; carbs aren't inherently bad, processed food is
  • Strict carnivore argument‚Äîyou don't need carbs if you're fat-adapted; honey and fruit are still sugar
  • The real answer‚Äîit depends on your goals, activity level, and how you personally respond
  • How to decide‚Äîstart strict for 90 days, then test if needed. Your body will tell you.

This debate is raging in the community right now. Let's break down both sides and what people are actually experiencing.

Core Arguments:

  • Carbs aren't bad‚Äîprocessed food and seed oils are the problem
  • Active people need glycogen for performance
  • Honey and fruit are "clean" carbs humans evolved eating
  • Zero-carb can cause electrolyte issues
Protocol: Meat, organs, fruit, honey, raw dairy. No grains, no seed oils, no processed food.

Core Arguments:

  • You don't need carbs‚Äîhumans are fat-adapted
  • Honey and fruit are still sugar (fructose = liver load)
  • Elimination works by eliminating everything
  • Adding carbs back reintroduces potential triggers
Protocol: Meat, water, salt. Maybe eggs and dairy if tolerated. No plants, no exceptions.

What Paul Saladino Actually Says

1

Carbs aren't inherently bad

The problem with the Standard American Diet isn't carbs‚Äîit's industrial foods. Honey and fruit are "clean" carbs that humans have eaten for thousands of years.

2

Active people perform better with carbs

Athletes, people who do intense exercise, and people with high stress might perform better with some glucose. Honey and fruit provide that without the downsides of grains.

3

Electrolyte balance is easier with carbs

Zero-carb carnivore can cause low aldosterone, which messes with sodium retention. Adding carbs helps your body hold onto electrolytes better.

"The debate isn't really about science. It's about individual response. Some people thrive on zero-carb. Some people do better with a little fruit. Both can work."

What Strict Carnivores Say

1

You don't need carbs‚Äîhumans are fat-adapted

Once you're fat-adapted (usually 3-6 months in), your body runs on fat and ketones. Your liver makes what little glucose you need via gluconeogenesis.

2

Honey and fruit are still sugar

Fructose from fruit goes straight to your liver and can cause the same metabolic issues as table sugar if you eat too much. Honey is basically glucose and fructose. It's not magic.

3

Elimination works because you eliminate everything

A lot of people come to carnivore because they have autoimmune issues, gut problems, or inflammation. Strict carnivore removes all potential triggers. Adding fruit back might reintroduce problems.

What the Community Actually Experiences

I've been watching this debate play out on Reddit, YouTube, and Discord for months. Here's what people are saying:

‚úì Better on Strict Carnivore (zero-carb)

"I tried adding honey back in and my skin broke out again. Strict carnivore keeps me clear."
"Carbs make me hungry. Zero-carb keeps my appetite stable."
"I came to carnivore to heal my gut. Adding fruit gave me bloating again."
"I feel mentally sharper on zero-carb. Ketones are better brain fuel for me."

üçØ Better on Animal-Based (with carbs)

"I do CrossFit 5 days a week. Adding honey pre-workout gave me my performance back."
"Zero-carb made me feel flat and low-energy. A little fruit fixed it."
"I was getting insomnia and heart palpitations on strict carnivore. Adding carbs fixed my electrolytes."
"I'm a woman and zero-carb tanked my hormones. Adding fruit brought my cycle back."

Both groups exist. Both are telling the truth about their own experience.

Who Benefits from Each Protocol

üçØ Consider Adding Carbs If:

  • Athletes and highly active people ‚Äî Intense training depletes glycogen. Honey or fruit can top off stores without processed carbs.
  • Women with hormonal issues ‚Äî Some women report better cycle regularity and thyroid function with carbs.
  • Electrolyte struggles ‚Äî If you get heart palpitations, dizziness, or insomnia despite supplementing salt, carbs might help retention.
  • Very lean before starting ‚Äî If you don't have much body fat to burn, carbs can provide quick energy.

‚úì Stay Strict Carnivore If:

  • Autoimmune conditions ‚Äî Elimination works because you eliminate everything. Adding plants back can reintroduce triggers.
  • Insulin resistance or diabetes ‚Äî Carbs spike insulin. Zero-carb keeps insulin low and stable.
  • Significant weight to lose ‚Äî Zero-carb makes appetite control easier. Adding carbs can trigger cravings.
  • Gut issues (IBS, SIBO, Crohn's) ‚Äî Fiber and fructose can feed bad bacteria. Strict carnivore starves them out.

The Nuanced Take

Here's what I think is actually happening:

The debate isn't really about science. It's about individual response. Some people thrive on zero-carb. Some people do better with a little fruit. Both can work.

Paul Saladino is a super active guy who surfs and works out constantly. For him, carbs improve performance. That doesn't mean everyone needs them.

Shawn Baker is also super active (he's a former pro athlete). He thrives on zero-carb. That doesn't mean carbs are inherently bad.

Different people, different results.

How to Figure Out What Works for You

If you're new to carnivore, start strict. Meat, water, salt. Give it 90 days.

Why? Because you need to establish a baseline. You need to be fully fat-adapted before you can assess whether carbs help or hurt.

After 90 days, if you're feeling great, keep going. If you're struggling with energy, sleep, or hormones, you can experiment with adding carbs back in.

How to Test:

  • Add one source of carbs at a time. Honey first, or fruit. Don't add both at once.
  • Start small: 1-2 tablespoons of honey, or one piece of fruit per day.
  • Track how you feel: energy, sleep, digestion, skin, mood.
  • If it helps, keep it. If it causes problems, remove it again.

This is your body. You get to decide what works.

The Bottom Line

Paul Saladino isn't wrong. But he's not universally right either.

For some people, adding honey and fruit improves performance and well-being. For others, it reintroduces cravings, inflammation, and metabolic problems.

The community is split because both approaches work for different people.

If strict carnivore is working for you, you don't need to change. If you're struggling and suspect carbs might help, you can test it without abandoning the core principles: prioritize animal foods, avoid processed junk, listen to your body.

That's the real lesson here. There's no one perfect protocol. There's only what works for you.

Key Takeaways

  1. Both protocols work‚Äîstrict carnivore and animal-based each have success stories
  2. Paul's argument‚Äîactive people may benefit from carbs; honey and fruit are "clean" sources
  3. Strict carnivore argument‚Äîyou don't need carbs if fat-adapted; sugar is sugar
  4. Athletes and women may benefit from some carbs; autoimmune and metabolic issues often do better strict
  5. Start strict for 90 days to establish a baseline before experimenting
  6. Test one thing at a time‚Äîadd honey OR fruit, not both, and track your response
  7. The real principle‚Äîprioritize animal foods, avoid processed junk, listen to your body

‚ÄîChloe

This is community observation, not medical advice. Both strict carnivore and animal-based can work. Consult a healthcare provider before making dietary changes.
